statement.p: Below is a topographic map showing part of Buck River and its surrounding area.
A hiker walks (in a straight line) from point A to point B. Describe what happens to their elevation along the way?

ol.li: At point A, the hiker starts at 1500 ft. They walk downhill for about 3 miles, reaching about 1175 ft. Then they walk uphill for 3 miles until they return to 1500 ft. at point B.
The hiker starts at an elevation of 1500 ft and remains at that elevation for the entire hike.
At point A, the hiker starts at 1500 ft. They walk uphill for about 4 miles, reaching about 1825 ft. Then they walk downhill for 2 miles until they return to 1500 ft at point B.

statement.p: What is the average rate of change in elevation when you walk from point C to point D?
Does the Buck River flow north-to-south or south-to-north?

ul.li: C: At point A, the hiker starts at 1500 ft. They walk uphill for about 4 miles, reaching about 1825 ft. Then they walk downhill for 2 miles until they return to 1500 ft at point B.
At point A, the hiker starts at 1500 ft. They walk uphill for about 4 miles, reaching about 1825 ft. Then they walk downhill for 2 miles until they return to 1500 ft at point B.
The average rate of change is (2000 ft - 1500 ft)/ (3 mi) = 500/3 ft/mi = 166.67 ft/mi.

The Buck River flows north-to-south because water flows downhill. As we travel north-to-south, the Buck River encounters contours at height 1400 ft, 1300 ft, 1200 ft, 1100 ft. So this must be the direction of flow.
